Award.AwardTitle: IUSE: Collaborative Project: Engaged Student Learning: Design and Development, Level I: Broadening the Path to the STEM Profession through Cybersecurity Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The significance and importance of this project resides in the diversification and broadening of the STEM talent pipeline in cybersecurity in predominantly undergraduate and liberal arts schools (small institutions). This is achieved by the creation of a curriculum that accommodates students of different levels of computer literacy, that focuses on experiential learning, and that utilizes institutional collaboration via cloud computing. This project will mitigate the challenges small institutions currently face in the cybersecurity area, for example, a tight computer science curriculum and the inability to support the expensive infrastructure required for cybersecurity education. Integrated into this project is research as to whether using this new curriculum and the related online projects, students will attain the same, or an increase, level of cybersecurity learning.

This project will address the above challenges by creating a range of cybersecurity learning opportunities that emphasize hands-on and realistic experimentation for students in small institutions. First, this project will attract a diverse population of students by introducing cybersecurity topics through multiple paths of study and engagement. Students will be introduced to cybersecurity concepts through manageable, stand alone course modules and laboratory exercises. Interested students can study further by taking two cybersecurity focused courses and cybersecurity capstone projects created by this project. Using all these materials students can create a cybersecurity concentration. Second, the project will use the Global Environment for Network Innovation (GENI) infrastructure in the development of empirical labs and the capstone project assignments. GENI offers an affordable cloud solution to small institutions that lack the infrastructure to support sophisticated computer labs. The learning impact of the new curriculum will be evaluated by quantitative competency assessments that are administered yearly. Student cybersecurity persistence will be assessed by a longitudinal study of the number of cybersecurity courses taken during a student's course of study. Qualitative assessment of the curriculum will take the form of student interviews and focus groups to gauge attitude towards course modules, perception of learning gains and comfort level with the pedagogies employed. In addition to the collaboration of three college level institutions, this project will leverage relationships with local community colleges to further develop a cybersecurity workforce. This partnership provides a diverse set of students that will support the evidence-based evaluation of student cybersecurity learning via this approach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cyber security has become a daily staple in dinner table conversations due to media outlets publicizing a continuous stream of hacking incidents that attract the public’s attention. Sensationalizing these attacks has forced public and private institutions to reprioritize and invest in their digital security protocols and practices. In 2017, the Global Information Security Workforce Study, conducted by the Center for Cyber Safety and Education and (ISC)², found that the cybersecurity workforce gap is on pace to hit 1.8 million by 2022 – a 20% increase since 2015. Colleges and universities are developing different strategies and programs to mitigate this talent gap, for example: new undergraduate degrees in cyber science, new accreditation criteria, and new online programs.

The focus of this project is to study a different approach to filling the technical job gap by: (1) offering meaningful learning opportunities to liberal arts students that may not by default chose to major in the field of cybersecurity, (2) developing hands-on experiences for Liberal Arts College (LIA) professors that need support to teach cybersecurity courses with limited resources.  The  listed outcomes of this project have contributed towards these goals: (1) non-intrusive curriculum for LIA colleges has been developed. This curriculum has built upon a required general education course, the first year experience seminar, to expose non-Computer Science (CS) majors to cybersecurity. An introduction to cybersecurity course has also been developed without requirements for any major that is interested in the field, (2) hands on technical labs using the Global Environment for Network Innovations (GENI) cloud infrastructure have been published. GENI is an academic cloud platform for network experimentation and it is free for any academic institution, making these hands-on labs affordable to anyone, (3) successfully organized three workshops at the College of Charleston and offered three workshops at professional events, to disseminate the material and assist LIA instructors in their goals to teach cybersecurity. As a result, several schools in the nation are using the project materials, implementing introductory courses on cybersecurity and hands on learning experiences for LIA students.

A three-year assessment led to findings that will inspire cybersecurity education improvements. By measuring the knowledge increase in the non-CS majors, we have indicated that there is positive impact on awareness and knowledge offered by the introductory and general education courses of this project. One interesting finding was that students’ perception of their own competence as technically conscious citizens and being able to secure their digital devices became more realistic after taking the introductory courses. Their confidence in their ability to deliver absolute security decreased, however this indicates that they learned about the limits of their knowledge and how they can improve upon it. A positive result was the opening of paths to cybersecurity for non-traditionally technical, LIA students. We observed an increase in their perception that any major should study cybersecurity and their awareness that they can solve problems for the field. The high impact of this project can be demonstrated by: (1) over 250 non-CS students that were exposed to cybersecurity at the College of Charleston, a primarily undergraduate LIA institution, (2) the mentorship of seven students in cybersecurity research and capstones that lead to multiple awards, peer reviewed publications, and careers in the cybersecurity field, and (3) more than 100 LIA and primarily undergraduate college professors’ participation in the organized workshops that are applying the labs and curriculum of this project in their institutions nationwide.
